dlg_turns.agent_utterance: A significant landmark judgment in Indian Criminal Law within the last 5 years is the decriminalization of consensual homosexual acts in private, achieved through the striking down of Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code to that extent [2] [10]. This historic, unanimous decision was delivered by a five-judge bench of the Supreme Court [2]. Prior to this, Section 377 criminalized "carnal intercourse against the order of nature," which was interpreted to include homosexual acts [7] [10]. The Supreme Court's ruling in *Union Of India* (2018) declared Section 377 unconstitutional insofar as it criminalized consensual homosexual acts between adults, marking a major milestone for LGBTQ+ rights in India [2] [10]. This effectively overturned the previous stance where Section 377 was upheld, as seen in the *Naz Foundation* case [7].

dlg_turns.agent_utterance:
In recent years, significant landmark judgments in Indian law have emerged across several key areas, most notably constitutional law and criminal law, with other areas also seeing important developments [3] [5].

Constitutional Law: The Supreme Court has delivered several landmark judgments in constitutional law from January to May 2024 [3]. A key area of focus has been the independence of the judiciary, with cases such as ALL INDIA JUDGES ASSOCIATION vs UNION OF INDIA being particularly important [1] [10]. Judgments related to OBC reservations in the All India Quota for PG NEET admissions also stand out as significant constitutional law decisions [9].

Criminal Law: A historic decision was made by a five-judge bench regarding Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code, which decriminalized it [5]. Cases such as Bilkis Yakub Rasool v. also fall under this category, marking significant precedents [2].

Other Areas: While the provided information does not detail specific landmark judgments in environmental law, it does highlight activity in areas like family law, with High Courts delivering important judgments on topics such as alimony and maintenance, divorce, and child custody [8]. Additionally, cases like Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited vs Assistant Commissioner Of Income Tax indicate developments in tax law [4]. There have also been important judgments in insurance law, as seen in UNITED INDIA INSURANCE CO. LTD. Vs 1. RUKMINI DEEPAK ALIAS DILIP KACHARE AND ORS [6].

dlg_turns.agent_utterance:
Recent Supreme Court judgments have significantly impacted the interpretation and application of Article 21 of the Indian Constitution, which guarantees the right to life and personal liberty [7].

One key area of development concerns digital access and its relation to Article 21. In *Amar Jain V Union of India and Ors.* (May 2025), the Supreme Court affirmed that inclusive and meaningful digital access to e-governance is integral to the right to life and personal liberty [2] [8]. This has practical implications for lawyers defending individual liberties, as it broadens the scope of Article 21 to include access to digital resources necessary for exercising fundamental rights.

The right to privacy, as an essential aspect of Article 21, was unanimously upheld by the Supreme Court [5]. This reinforces the idea that personal liberty extends to informational privacy, impacting how lawyers argue cases involving data protection and surveillance.

Furthermore, the Supreme Court's stance on Article 21 emphasizes that any deprivation of life or personal liberty must adhere to procedures established by law [7]. The Supreme Court has also clarified that it can intervene if there is an imminent threat to the violation of Article 21 [6]. This empowers lawyers to challenge actions that threaten individual liberties, even before they fully materialize.

The Supreme Court has also addressed instances where an individual's right to liberty under Article 21 is allegedly violated due to successive detentions [9].
dlg_turns.user_utterance: Could you discuss any recent landmark Supreme Court judgments related to Article 21 (Right to Life and Personal Liberty) of the Indian Constitution and their practical implications for lawyers defending individual liberties?
